title: 112_s477
content: The Act titled "Government Excess Prevention Act of 2011" limits government printing costs. The "Government Excess Prevention Act of 2011" mandates the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to work with Federal departments to reduce printing costs, establish guidelines on employee printing, and publish cost-benefit analysis results on the office's website. The "Government Excess Prevention Act of 2011" requires the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to oversee cost-saving measures, including implementing digital signature systems and monitoring employee printing. Guidelines must be issued for departments to disclose information on publications. The "Government Excess Prevention Act of 2011" mandates the disclosure of information on publications, including the number of copies printed, production cost, and the publishing firm's name. SEC. 3. LIMITATION OF GOVERNMENT TRAVEL COSTS. The total amount paid or reimbursed by an agency for travel and subsistence expenses under chapter 57 of title 5, United States Code, cannot exceed 50 percent of the total amount for the fiscal year after the enactment of this Act for 5 fiscal years. Exceptions include expenses for threatened law enforcement personnel and other established exceptions under subsection (c). Regulations for national security or public safety reasons shall be prescribed by the respective authorities responsible for regulations under section 5707 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 4. REDUCTION IN FEDERAL VEHICLE COSTS. The text chunk outlines a reduction in federal vehicle costs by rescinding 20% of unobligated funds for new vehicles in fiscal year 2011 and limiting the amount available for new vehicle acquisitions in subsequent years to 80% of the previous year's funding. The General Services Administration is limited to acquiring only 50% of the new vehicles acquired for the Federal fleet in fiscal year 2011. Amounts from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 for new vehicles are not considered in the baseline calculation.
